The benefits of aerobic exercise are firmly established on a sizeable body of evidence from randomized controlled trials. However, the current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from good-quality, contemporary trials is required in order to assess the effectiveness of community-based, aerobic exercise program to reduce risk for CVD.

However, this does not exclude the possible usefulness of therapeutic monitoring of patients with ischemic stroke during the acute phase of ischemic stroke, with the aim of reaching predefined outcomes.

We conducted a randomized trial at 30 centers to determine whether mild intraoperative hypothermia refers to a mortality benefit from cerebral aneurysm clipping or not. There is no apparent benefit from hypothermia in patients with aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage. The results suggest that a small number of patients with cerebral aneurysm clipping may benefit from mild intubated hypothermia during cerebral aneurysm surgery. However, this does not apply to all patients.

The current evidence base is limited due to the differing methodologies employed in the trials and inconsistencies in reporting of outcomes. Further evidence from good-quality, contemporary trials is required in order to assess the effectiveness of topical corticosteroid therapy compared to control groups or other corticosteroid therapy in patients with active Crohn's disease.
